text: hey everybody Anthony feat Ana here
Internet by Munna Minard and it's time
for a review of the new black milk album
no poison no paradise black milk the
pseudonym for detroit-based
MC and producer Curtis cross the dude
has been producing albums collaborating
with other artists for years he's pretty
much a seasoned vet at this point he's
worked with people like let's see J
Dilla Black Thought lsi you know another
slum village connection they're guilty
Simpson and Shaun price on that random
acts album as well as Pharoahe Monch he
was an early supporter of Danny Brown as
well not one of the biggest names out
there but very well known in the
underground well-known where he's from
at least in the world of hip-hop and he
has a strong affinity for boom-bap hip
hop as well as jazz rap soul samples but
he is a purveyor of bold experimentation
- he's not afraid to put together a
strange beat and off-kilter beat a dark
beat especially on this album I mean
look at that cover not exactly sunny
days and birds tweeting now I was not
crazy about this guy's last full-length
LP album of the year what do you want me
to say I just feel like on that album it
was so apparent that black milk's
lyrical abilities are not really up
there with his production abilities and
while yeah that's sort of a consistent
thing throughout all of his LPS
maybe the gap was wider there than it
ever has been before but I no poison no
paradise I think that gap is closing in
a pretty big way I wouldn't say
lyrically Black Milk is blowing me away
but certainly what he doesn't have
inflow or sort of really clever
punchlines he makes up for in just how
reflective personal relatable and a
descriptive of his life his experiences
this album is the instrumentals on this
thing the beats the kicks
thud the snares are dirty he loves to
use a lot of sawtooth wave synthesizers
I usually prefer a very smooth
square-wave but they work in his favor a
lot of the time make his beats really
rough and they add to that grimy feel
that he loves to deliver he's really
great at bringing together some jazzy
samples on this record some soulful
samples on this record as well and I
would say that even though no poison no
paradise is a pretty grimy album I mean
there's just filth on this LP urban
decay uh still that does not stop it
from being really melodic cinematic the
track interpret sabotage which opens
this album up it's a great track a
killer opener a song that lyrically
seems to be about Black Milk kind of
aging in the rap game fighting to stay
relevant fighting to stay interesting
continue giving fans that next evolution
that new [ __ ] and he talks about this in
a really speedy and passionate flow and
it brings the song some serious urgency
and the instrumental here has a very
simple drum beat but it is lifted with
some very nicely placed synthesizer
strings and some very catchy melodic
leads as well usually a much bigger on
sample based hip-hop you know I just
love the way that samples get twisted
and looped and so on and so forth but I
really am drawn toward a lot of the
synth based stuff that Black Milk does
on this LP like the song ghetto DMF
which is obviously a reference to the
Detroit electronic music festival and
that electronic feel is sort of
reflected in the beat with the heavy use
of synthesizers and the skittering
hi-hats
the synthesizer sort of have a phaser
quality to them really the track with
reference to this festival is more of a
very gritty and dark portrait of the
city that he comes from and quali Criss
drops in on the back end with a lyrical
feature with a with a very Randy verse I
love the instrumental to the song dismal
as well another dark track and synth
heavy track it's got a bit of an eerie
Halloween vibe to it but still very
gritty and lyrically it's a song where
Black Milk kind of reflects on a loss a
shrinkage in his fame in his success and
how that's a bit of psychological
torture to him I also love the roughs in
leads and the bubbling arpeggios on
attract parallels it's a nice backdrop
to black milk's lyrics which are kind of
romantic seductive about attraction to
this woman and sort of a very intimate
moment that they're having and I like
the song moneybags too which is also
very synth heavy and funky because of it
the leads on this thing are bright
they're kind of noisy the production is
solid the issue is that the tracks that
are less lyrically driven maybe the
beats are not wowing enough or
progressed enough or detailed enough to
be interesting from beginning to end
like the track Sonny jr. which is a song
that has Robert Glasper appearing
musically very nice jazz hip hop fusion
and a good groove just not a track that
to me is fiery and interesting from
beginning to end and then there's the
song X chords which is one of the more
playful tracks on this LP where the
synthesizers are kind of cartoony but I
don't find every melodic element in this
track to be all that interesting to me
the song ends up more of a mess than
anything and maybe that was kind of
intentional because of how
tongue-in-cheek the song feels but maybe
there is sort of an issue with song
structure occasionally on this album
because it does hinder some of the
lyrically driven songs on here like
codes and cab fares with black thought
and because of how subdued and
underwhelming the instrumental and sort
of the pacing of the song is even though
I do like how dark and moody the song is
and I do like the lyrics on this track
too when Black Thought finally appears
it seems like such an anti climactic
moment and there are moments on here too
where the overall rough and somewhat
lo-fi sound of this album does kind of
hold it back a bit especially when it
comes to Black Milk EQ ngahiwi tongue a
track that features a lot of pianos
organs some tight drum fills and this
very soulful instrumental serves as a
nostalgic backdrop for Black Milk to
kind of spit and wax poetic about older
times when he would hang out with his
friend the real sort of subject of this
track
is sort of how Black Milk is having a
hard time getting along with this
person's mother and how she sees him is
you get out of here it's a pretty funny
trip down memory lane but there are some
moments here where it feels like Black
Milk is a little underwhelming
poetically about how he takes the blame
because everyone expects him to be
insane or the closing track on here
where he says that because he's not able
to pay his bills he feels like he's
falling there's also a line on this
track as well where it's like if you
don't make dollars then you don't make
sense
some of the Rhymes and wordplay on this
album are basic but maybe not as
laughably so as it was on album of the
year and I do feel like again this is
sort of made up for by the very true to
life and from the harsh storytelling
that Black Milk is delivering like on
the song Sunday's best and Monday's
worst which the Sunday's best track has
a sample that feels gospel inspired and
it's a song about being a kid and
getting up on Sunday going to church the
family the deacon you're pretending to
be sick you'd rather be playing video
games it's all there
later in the track referencing how as an
adult he sort of chose the wrong path
made some bad moves and that's
essentially where the track Monday's
worst comes in where we find Black Milk
sort of plotting on doing some dirt
robbing this guy who's drunk outside of
a club taking his chain and I love the
soulful hook on this track to sing about
how it's never too late to get your
values straight and it's cool to see
this connection between these two tracks
and there are other connections between
two tracks on here as well other pairs
of tracks songs like parallels as well
as X chords because X chord sort of
seems to be the sexy moment that follows
the seduction of parallels and then
there is Sonny jr. which is kind of like
this jazzy dream sequence before
Sunday's best then there's also
perfected on Putnam Ave which is kind of
this dreamy positive light-hearted trip
backwards into nostalgia land like many
other tracks on here are but right after
that is the song dismal which is more
about the current adult state of affairs
where Black Milk is
sort of not seeing that much hope in his
career right now there are some
well-formed dichotomies on this LP
between the past and the present the
good and the bad making positive and
negative choices in your life being a
success being a failure but still
despite all of that hoping for the best
at the end of all of it I love this out
I think it's very good I think it's well
put together I think I have a few issues
with it maybe it's a little too low-key
I wish it was just more I guess in your
face with how great it is is is plus
there are some points where the mixing
is just okay in the vocally cueing like
I said and the clothes are on here the
money bags track while I do feel like
much of what Black Milk suffering sort
of comes down to is lack of money and
maybe that's why this track ends the
album off musically sonically it still
feels like a somewhat anti climactic
closure and not really the most poignant
finish to you know an album that seems
as personal and as reflective as this
there are some spots where I feel like
this album could be just tighter more
cohesive maybe flow a little bit better
in a storyline sort of way but still I I
feel like even in this disjointed State
no poison no paradise is still an
incredibly telling and uh relatable
album I'm feeling a light a decent eight
on this thing transition but if you've
given this album a listen what did you
think of it love it hate it why what do
you think I should review next and
that's it Anthony Fantana Black Milk
forever
